1.rationale:
I'm eyeing the apple at (6,6) because it's the closest in Manhattan distance from our snake's position (3,5). Moving from (3,5) to (3,6) brings our y coordinate in line with that apple, setting us up for a clear horizontal path in subsequent moves. There aren’t any immediate hazards—the enemy snake is far away, and none of our available adjacent squares threaten walls.

So, I'll move UP.

Let's first review the board and our snake’s state.

• Board recap:
 – Apples are at (1,8), (1,1), (0,2), (7,6), (4,3).
 – Our snake (“1”) is currently at (6,6) with part of its body (a tail segment "T") at (5,6) from our previous move.
 – The enemy snake (“2”) is at (6,1).

• Our current head position is (6,6). We want to avoid collisions with walls, enemy snake, or our own body. Moving back into our own “tail” (at (5,6)) is not allowed.

Let’s look at our possible moves from (6,6):

1. UP → (6,7)  
  • (6,7) is clear (no wall, apple, or own body), but no apple there.
2. RIGHT → (7,6)  
  • (7,6) has an apple. Moving RIGHT would let us grab an apple, growing our snake and scoring 1 point.
3. DOWN → (6,5)  
  • (6,5) is also clear.

Given that our goal is to collect apples for score and growth, the apple at (7,6) is a prime target. It’s only one step to the right and there are no hazards blocking that move.

Thus, the best next move is to go RIGHT.

Strategy note for later turns:
• After eating the apple at (7,6), keep looking ahead to avoid boxing yourself in while going after the cluster of remaining apples. Also, monitor the enemy snake’s position to ensure safe paths.

Decided next move: RIGHT.

Looking at our board, our snake now occupies (5,6), (6,6) (its body) with the head at (7,6) after grabbing the apple. The remaining apples are at (1,8), (1,1), (0,2), (4,3), and (3,4). From our current head at (7,6) the available moves (without turning back into our own body) are:

• UP → (7,7)  
  – This is safe but it moves us farther from the cluster of apples at (4,3) and (3,4).  
• RIGHT → (8,6)  
  – Safe as well but moves us away from the apples.  
• DOWN → (7,5)  
  – This move brings us closer to the nearer apples. For example, from (7,5) the Manhattan distance to (3,4) is 4 (|7–3| + |5–4| = 4 + 1 = 5) and similarly to (4,3).

Since we cannot move LEFT (that would lead us to (6,6), which is occupied by our own body), and since our goal is to continue pursuing apples while avoiding our tail and other hazards, moving DOWN sets us up nicely for eventually turning left toward the cluster of apples. 

Thus, my decided next move is: DOWN.

I’m looking at the board from our current head at (7,5). Our body occupies (6,6) and (5,6), so moving UP isn’t an option since (7,6) isn’t free (it’s actually occupied by our body). That leaves us with three choices:

• DOWN to (7,4): This move would bring us slightly closer to the nearby apple cluster (the apples at (3,4) and (4,3)). From (7,4) the Manhattan distance to (4,3) would be |7–4| + |4–3| = 3 + 1 = 4.  
• LEFT to (6,5): This move directly decreases our x coordinate toward the cluster. From (6,5) the distance to (4,3) becomes |6–4| + |5–3| = 2 + 2 = 4.  
• RIGHT to (8,5): Although safe, this moves us away from the group of nearby apples on the left.

Both DOWN and LEFT get us closer, but moving LEFT preserves a more direct horizontal alignment with our target apples, setting us up for subsequent downward moves if needed without risk of boxing ourselves in.

Thus, I decide the next move will be LEFT.
